content:
Diagnosis:

Mixed corticomedullary adrenal tumor with local invasion

CT abdomen 15 March 2024 - 8.2cm right adrenal mass with invasion into posterior abdominal wall musculature. No distant metastases.

Previous medical history:
Hypertension - well controlled
Type 2 diabetes
Hypothyroidism

Current medications:
Metformin 1g bd
Levothyroxine 100mcg od
Amlodipine 5mg od

Allergies:
None known

Current situation:
24-hour urinary catecholamines show elevated noradrenaline at 1240nmol/24h (normal <600)
Serum cortisol 890nmol/L with loss of diurnal variation
Aldosterone/renin ratio normal

I reviewed [redacted name] today who was referred following the incidental finding of a right adrenal mass on ultrasound performed for abdominal pain. She is a 56-year-old lady who initially presented with a 6-month history of right-sided abdominal discomfort, episodes of palpitations, and worsening hypertension despite medication. She has also noticed increased anxiety and sweating episodes over the past few months.

On examination, she has a blood pressure of 158/94mmHg with a regular pulse of 88bpm. There is some tenderness in the right upper quadrant but no palpable mass. No peripheral oedema or signs of Cushing's syndrome.

I have discussed the findings with our endocrine surgery colleagues. Given the mixed hormonal profile and local invasion, we recommend proceeding with an open right adrenalectomy. She will require pre-operative alpha blockade with phenoxybenzamine followed by beta blockade. I have arranged admission next week for blood pressure optimization and pre-operative assessment.

The plan is for surgery in approximately 4 weeks once adequate alpha blockade is achieved. We will see her weekly in the pre-assessment clinic to titrate medications. I have provided written information about the surgery and arranged for our specialist nurse to contact her tomorrow to discuss any questions.
